R2: I'd love to explore the question of how we navigate authentic decision-making when so much of ourselves remains opaque to us. I've been thinking about this iceberg metaphor - how most of what drives our choices, preferences, and reactions happens below conscious awareness. It makes me curious about the practical side of this: How do any of us trust ourselves to make important decisions when we can't fully understand our own motivations? There's something both unsettling and fascinating about the courage required to act authentically while accepting that we're fundamentally mysterious to ourselves. I wonder if this uncertainty is actually a feature rather than a bug - maybe the opacity forces us to pay attention to subtler signals, to develop a different kind of self-trust.
